items.content:
#â€‹571 â€” December 7, 2022 | Read on the web

The State of CSS 2022 â€” An always fascinating overview of the evolving CSS landscape. This yearâ€™s results highlight the speed at which changes and new features have been coming in, and the impressive rate at which they are being adopted, both by browser vendors and developers alike. The big highlights of the year? Parent selectors such as :has(), container queries, and the emergingÂ Subgrid. An essential end of year read.

Devographics

React Authentication, Simplified â€” In this article, we lay out a new approach to authentication (plus access control & SSO) in ReactÂ applications.

Userfront sponsor

A Practical Guide to CSS Media Queries â€” A closer look at media queries, sharing how they work, how to use them correctly, breakpoints, examples, and looking at the different device types that can be specified directly with the @media property.

Alex Ivanovs

Setting Up a Screen Reader Testing Environment â€” Accessibility expert Sara shares how to get set up with a screen reader â€”Â a crucial step when performing manual testing, as youâ€™ll be able to catch and fix accessibility issues that cannot be caught by automated testingÂ tools.

Sara Soueidan

Landmarks and Where to Put Them â€” An introduction to landmark elements (a bunch of elements that help you define the structure of a page, think nav, main, etc) and advice about their ideal position andÂ structure.

Kilian Valkhof

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • Google is switching to continuous scrolling for search results on desktop (for the first six traditional pages of results, at least).

  • Nic Mulvaney looks at how to count unique visitors without using typical cookies, UIDs or fingerprinting â€“ some cache trickery is afoot.

  • Here's a look at what's new in DevTools in Chrome 108 (including hints for inactive CSS properties).

  • ...and here's what's new in the DevTools of Microsoft Edge 107.

  • WYSIWYG! It's been 25 years since the debut of Microsoft Frontpage 98.

This half-hour talk considers the purpose of this, the ways its constructed in different browsers, and the impact it has on both performance and experience for people who use assistiveÂ technology.

Shortcut (formerly Clubhouse.io) sponsor

Kevin Powell

Advanced Web Font Optimization Techniques â€” Some advanced techniques to be aware of to help make your site faster and to create a better user experience when using webÂ fonts.

Alex Barashkov

Why You Should Be Using New CSS Features Today â€” A two part series on new CSS features (such as cascade layers, :has(), nesting, andÂ more).

Brecht De Rutye

Maybe the best part is the list of â€œunusual applicationsâ€ (e.g. ability to create an â€œemptyâ€ tweet). Use for good, not evil.

Florian Pigorsch

Daniel Roe

items.title: Three new CSS dynamic viewport units
items.content:
#â€‹570 â€” November 30, 2022 | Read on the web

The Large, Small, and Dynamic Viewport Units â€” These three new CSS units (lvh, svh, dvh) account for mobile viewports with dynamic toolbars. This post explains why we need such new units, how they interact with the viewport on mobile browsers, and highlights some caveats to be aware of. Support ships in Chrome 108. Firefox and Safari already haveÂ support.

Bramus Van Damme

Color Formats in CSS â€” Josh takes us on a tour of the slew of color formats at our disposal (hex, RGB, HSL, etc.), looking at how they work and how to get the best out ofÂ them. As with any of Josh's posts, there's a lot to dig intoÂ here.

Josh W. Comeau

Fast and Flexible Gantt Chart Component for Your Web App â€” Bryntum's suite of web components includes powerful Gantt and resource scheduling widgets used by thousands of businesses. The API is extremely flexible and allows you to configure everything from colors to details of the scheduling logic. Free 45-dayÂ trial.

Bryntum sponsor

The BBC's 15 Web Principles: 15 Years Later â€” Back in 2007 â€“ an eternity in web years â€“ the BBC published a document showing their â€˜15 Web Principlesâ€™. This post looks back at how such 'early-web-2.0 idealism' stacks upÂ today.

Terence Eden

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • In another blast from the past, this piece from 1999 calls HTML a "strategic dead end" and something which treats "intelligent devices [..] as dumbed down display devices". Eek!

  • There has been plenty of thoughtful feedback to the UK's consultation on mobile browsers, app stores, and competition.

  • ICYMI last week, Josh Comeau's interactive guide to all things Flexbox is well worth a read.

Document Object Model (DOM) Geometry: A Beginnerâ€™s Introduction and Guide â€” Analyzes the methods and properties that make user interface solutions such as infinite scrolling, animating elements on scroll, or even the popular drag and drop achievable, and afterward, dives into some practical use cases forÂ them.

Pearl Akpan

â–¶Â Â Stop Fighting with CSS Positioning â€” A 20-minute look at using CSS positioning effectively, which often comes down to understanding CSS containing blocks, and how positioning influencesÂ it.

Kevin Powell

The State of Notifications Report - User Preferences â€” What is preventing us from designing a notification system that facilitates a betterÂ experience?

Courier.com sponsor

Tailwind is a Leaky Abstraction â€” â€œTailwind is a layer on top of CSS, but it doesnâ€™t actually hide any complexity in the layer below. You still need to know CSS.â€ This one generated a fair bit of discussion on HackerÂ News.

Jake Lazaroff

What Working with Tailwind CSS Every Day for Two Years LooksÂ Like â€” ...and another take on Tailwind: â€œI consider Tailwind CSS to be one of the boring established CSS solutions that enables me to be the most productive in building and maintaining projects of variousÂ sizes.â€

Mosaad

Building Conscious Design Systems â€” Amy asks how we can focus less on artefacts in design systems, and work consciously to build inclusive design systems â€œthat put people at theirÂ heartâ€.

items.title: An epic, interactive guide to Flexbox
items.content:
#â€‹569 â€” November 23, 2022 | Read on the web

An Interactive Guide to Flexbox â€” A new, interactive explainer from Josh, with over 20 demos showing off how Flexbox works. This is an excellent, detailed overview, and a real sound way to wrap your head around the core flexboxÂ functions. There's a lot to enjoy here and even if you think you know your Flexbox already, it's a greatÂ refresher.

Josh W. Comeau

Building Powerful and Faster Data Grid With Kendo UI for Angular â€” Letâ€™s see how the Kendo UI for Angular Grid can be used to create a robust data grid, and how it compares to AngularÂ Material.

Progress Kendo UI for Angular sponsor

Experimenting with Layering, Filtering, and Masking in CSS â€” Jeff shares some findings following recent experiments with layering, filtering, and masking in CSS. They note that the language has come a long way in recent years, with properties like filter, mask-image, mix-blend-mode, additional gradient types like radial-gradient, and more, opening the door for Photoshop-like effects that werenâ€™t possibleÂ before.

Jeff Zych

A Guide to Keyboard Accessibility with JavaScript â€” The first article in this series looked at HTML and CSS accessibility, and this second entry focuses on JavaScript. It covers a JS toolset you can use to create a great experience for keyboard-orientedÂ users.

Cristian Diaz

âš¡ï¸ IN BRIEF

  • The 2022 State of JavaScript survey is open and here's what's new.

  • Work with Wordpress? They have a new, official developer blog.

  • The UK's 'Competition and Markets Authority' has launched an investigation into Apple & Googleâ€™s â€œeffective duopolyâ€ on mobile ecosystems.

  • Sara Soueidan's Practical Accessibility course is open for pre-order.

  • Browser updates:

    • Firefox Nightly and Developer Edition will now support Manifest v3 browser extensions. The latest Firefox Nightly also now has Container Queries enabled.

    • IE 11 will be permanently disabled on certain versions of Windows 10 in February. Prepare for panic from mid-sized corporations and my localÂ library.

    • Safari Technology Preview 158 is out with updates to the web inspector, WebCodecs support, font-size-adjust implementation, API improvements, and more.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

Tree Views in CSS â€” How to create a collapsible list (tree view) with just HTML and CSS, no need for JavaScript. Accessibility software will see the tree view as lists nested inside disclosure widgets, and the standard keyboard interaction is supportedÂ automatically.

Kate Rose Morley

Create Stunning og:image Tags Automatically â€” Check how you can set up beautiful and dynamic link previews automatically onÂ mugshotbot.com.

Mugshot Bot sponsor

Using Automated Test Results to Improve Accessibility â€” Looks at how to leverage automated test results from accessibility checks to see real, sustainable digital accessibilityÂ transformation.

Noah Mashni and Mark Steadman

Inline Layout Switch Ideas â€” Two ideas for animating images from an inline layout to a column or grid-based one â€”Â and as itâ€™s from Codrops, thereâ€™s demos ofÂ course.

It does cost money, though, but has a free trial and you can play around with the editor itself without signing up to see if you like the flow.

CSS Clothoid Corners: Generate "Visually Softer" Rounded Corners Using CSS clip-path â€” This online generator uses the CSS clip-path property to subtly improve the look of rounded corners on elements. The result is similar to the rounded edges on iOS appÂ icons. ('Clothoids' are also known as Euler spirals. Now you know.)
